data.title: Museum Mile Festival 2016: What to see and where to go.
data.meta_description: More than one million visitors of the Museum Mile Festival will have the opportunity to visit 7 world class NYC museums for free.
data.text:
38 years of Museum Mile Festivals

Now celebrating its 38th year, the annual Museum Mile Festival takes place rain or shine on June 14, 2016. During the event, more than one million visitors of the Museum Mile Festival will have the opportunity to visit 7 world class museums for free!

El Museo Del Barrio, Museum of the City of New York, the Jewish Museum, Cooper Hewitt National Design Museum, Neue Galerie New York, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum have special Festival programming planned for the evening. What to expect at each of these venues? Here is a sampling of the current exhibitions you can enjoy.

Guggenheim Museum: László Moholy-Nagy: Future Present

1071 Fifth Ave, New York, NY 10128. Open: Sun–Wed, Fri 10am–5:45pm and Sat 10am–7:45pm

Moholy-Nagy is a central figure in the history of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. In 1929, Guggenheim and his advisor, German-born artist Hilla Rebay, began collecting his paintings, works on paper, and sculpture in depth for the Guggenheim’s growing collection of nonobjective art. His work held a special place at the Museum of Non-Objective Painting—the forerunner of the Guggenheim Museum—where a memorial exhibition was presented shortly after his untimely death in 1946.

Other exhibitions on view at the Guggenheim include But a Storm is Blowing from Paradise: Contemporary Art of the Middle East and North Africa. East-African retro-pop band Alsarah and the Nubatones will perform, and museum educators will lead chalk drawing activities for families on Fifth Avenue. All ages welcome.

Exhibition on view: May 27–September 7, 2016

El Museo Del Barrio: Antonio Lopez – Future Funk Fashion

1230 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10029. Open: Weds – Sat from 11am – 6pm & Sun 12pm – 5pm

Stop by El Museo during this years Museum Mile Festival for a performance by It’s Showtime NYC, music by DJ Mickey Perez spinning Afro Latin disco, and art-making where you will design your own fashion accessory! Also, get a first look during opening day of ANTONIO LOPEZ: Future Funk Fashion. The exhibition features the late illustrator’s drawings, prototypes for fantasy shoes, his well-known instamatic photographs, portraits of various fashion world luminaries and archival photographs and various other objects.

¡Pasen por el Museo durante el Festival de Museum Mile donde tendremos un espectáculo especial de It’s Showtime NYC, música por DJ Mickey Perez tocando Afro Latin Disco, y talleres de arte para toda la familia!

Exhibition on view: June 14, 2016 – November 26, 2016

Museum of the City of New York: Roz Chast: Cartoon Memoirs

1220 Fifth Avenue at 104th Street, New York, NY 10029. Open: 7 days a week 10:00 am–6:00 pm

The Museum of the City of New York and Local Projects are teaming up to offer Museum Mile visitors a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to be part of the Museum’s groundbreaking exhibition New York at Its Core, coming November 2016. Dozens of festivalgoers will be offered the chance to strut their stuff as hoverboarders, urban farmers, and other future occupants of NYC. Participants may have their videos included in the innovative and interactive Future City Lab – one of three galleries making up New York at Its Core. All New Yorkers are welcome to participate, just visit the Museum during Museum Mile and find the auditorium for the film shoot we’re calling New Yorkers Needed. Those who wish to observe but not participate are more than welcome to stop by for a sneak peek at the making of the Museum’s most anticipated exhibition ever.

Exhibition on view: April 14 – October 9, 2016

Cooper Hewitt National Design Museum

2 East 91st Street (off Fifth Avenue) New York, NY 10128. Open: Weekdays and Sundays, 10:00 a.m.–6:00 p.m.

Saturdays, 10:00 a.m.–9:00 p.m

Enjoy family-friendly activities and special exhibitions on view, including: Beauty—Cooper Hewitt Design Triennial, Pixar: The Design of Story, Thom Browne Selects, Fragile Beasts, Energizing the Day: Gifts from the George R. Kravis II Collection,

and Immersion Room. More information here.

The Jewish Museum: Isaac Mizrahi: An Unruly History

1109 5th Ave at 92nd St New York, NY 10128. Open: Fri – Tues 11 am – 5:45 pm, Thursday, 11am – 8pm

Isaac Mizrahi: An Unruly History is organized thematically, exploring key trends in Mizrahi’s work — from the use of color and prints, to witty designs that touch on issues of race, religion, class, and politics. The core of the exhibition features iconic designs from the Isaac Mizrahi New York clothing label (1987 – 1998), the “semi-couture” collections (2003 – 2011), and the trailblazing line for Target (2002 – 2008). The show is comprised of 42 “looks” that include clothing, hats, jewelry, shoes, accessories, and costumes for the theater, the opera, and the Mark Morris Dance Group. Also featured are the designer’s original drawings, performance stills, and behind-the-scenes photographs.

Exhibition on view: March 18 – August 7, 2016

Neue Galerie New York: Selections from the permanent Collection

1048 Fifth Avenue at 86th street, New York, NY 10028. Open: Thur- Mon 11am – 6pm

The Neue Galerie invites attendees to visit the second floor gallery where Gustav Klimt‘s iconic portrait Adele Bloch-Bauer I (1907) hangs on permanent display. This work is joined by a selection of landscape and portrait paintings by Klimt, and a display of Austrian decorative arts from the early twentieth century.

At the museum’s front entrance, watch Australian cabaret performer Kim David Smith as he conjures the glitter, doom, and decadence of 1920’s Berlin with an intimate, musical portrait of the Weimar period through the works of Kurt Weill, Mischa Spoliansky, and many unexpected others.

More on Adele Bloch-Bauer on ArtEx

Exhibition on view: June 16, 2016-September 19, 2016

The Metropolitan Museum of Art: Transitional Object (PsychoBarn)

1000 Fifth Avenue at 82nd street, New York, NY 10028. Open: Sun–Thur: 10 am–5:30 pm, Fri and Sat: 10 am–9 pm

The Met has an extensive range of programs scheduled for the Festival. Here is a quick sampling and the rest you can find on the museum’s event page here.

Pop-up Performances

Experience pop-up performances throughout the Museum’s galleries with Dušan Týnek Dance Theatre.

6:30–8:30 pm

Floor 1

Chalk Drawing

Make your mark at The Met by adding to a collaborative chalk drawing on the Museum’s plaza with artist Raúl Ayala.

David H. Koch Plaza, near 83rd Street (weather permitting)

#MetKids Animation Stations

Collaborate with The Good School and other visitors on stop-motion animated films inspired by The Met’s African art collection. Met curator Yaëlle Biro and fellow Kristen Windmuller-Luna will be on hand to help answer your questions!

Floor 1, Gallery 350, Samuel H. and Linda M. Lindenbaum Galleries

Exhibition on view through October 31st, 2016

New York City has officially designated Fifth Avenue from 82nd to 105th streets “Museum Mile” because of the vast richness and cultural diversity of the seven museums found there.
